<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Maria_Sharapova skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Maria Sharapova</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p>{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
</p><p><b>Maria Yuryevna Sharapova</b> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> (<span lang="ru"><span class="unicode haudio" style="white-space:nowrap;"><span class="fn"><a href="/wiki/File:Loudspeaker.svg" title="File:Loudspeaker.svg">About this sound</a>&#160;<a href="/w/index.php?title=Special:Upload&amp;wpDestFile=Maria_sharapova.ogg" class="new" title="Maria sharapova.ogg">Мари́я Ю́рьевна Шара́пова</a></span>&#160;<small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">(<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_help" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Media help"><span style="cursor:help;">help</span></a>·<a href="/w/index.php?title=File:Maria_sharapova.ogg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="File:Maria sharapova.ogg (page does not exist)"><span style="cursor:help;">info</span></a>)</small></span></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>; born April 19, 1987) is a Russian professional <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a> player who as of January 6, 2014 is ranked World No. 3 by the <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Tennis_Association" title="Women's Tennis Association">Women's Tennis Association</a> (WTA) and is the top Russian player. A <a href="/wiki/Permanent_residence_(United_States)" title="Permanent residence (United States)">United States resident</a> since 1994,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> Sharapova has won twenty-nine <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Tennis_Association" title="Women's Tennis Association">WTA</a> singles titles, including four <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> singles titles. She has also won the year-end <a href="/w/index.php?title=2004_WTA_Tour_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2004 WTA Tour Championships – Singles (page does not exist)">WTA Tour Championships in 2004</a>. The WTA has ranked Sharapova <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_players&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of WTA number 1 ranked players (page does not exist)">World No. 1</a> in singles on five separate occasions, for a total of 21 weeks. She became the world no.&#160;1 for the first time on August 22, 2005, and last held the ranking for the fifth time for four weeks from June 11, 2012 to July 8, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> She has been in eight Grand Slam finals with a record of 4–4.
</p><p>Sharapova made her professional breakthrough in 2004 at age 17, when she defeated two-time defending champion and top seed <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2004_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2004 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2004 Wimbledon final</a> for her first Grand Slam singles title. She entered the top 10 of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=WTA_Rankings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WTA Rankings (page does not exist)">WTA Rankings</a> with the win. The world no. 1 ranking followed in 2005, along with subsequent major titles at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 US Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2006 US Open</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Australian Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2008 Australian Open</a>, before she was forced out of the game for ten months by a recurring shoulder injury, which ultimately required surgery in October 2008. Sharapova returned to the game in May 2009, returning to the top 10 in March 2011 and capturing her fourth Grand Slam title at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 French Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2012 French Open</a>. By doing so, she became the sixth woman in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Open_Era&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Open Era (page does not exist)">Open Era</a> to complete the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Career_Grand_Slam" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">career Grand Slam</a> in singles. In the same year, she won an <a href="/wiki/Olympic_medal" title="Olympic medal">Olympic silver medal</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=London_2012_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="London 2012 Olympics (page does not exist)">London 2012 Olympics</a>.
</p><p>Sharapova has been featured in a number of modeling assignments, including a feature in the <i><a href="/wiki/Sports_Illustrated_Swimsuit_Issue" title="Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue">Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue</a></i>. She has been featured in many advertisements, including for Nike, Prince, and Canon, and is the face of several <a href="/wiki/Fashion_house" title="Fashion house" class="mw-redirect">fashion houses</a>, most notably <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cole_Haan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cole Haan (page does not exist)">Cole Haan</a>. Since February 2007, she has been a <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNDP_Goodwill_Ambassador&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNDP Goodwill Ambassador (page does not exist)">United Nations Development Programme Goodwill Ambassador</a>, concerned specifically with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chernobyl_Recovery_and_Development_Programme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chernobyl Recovery and Development Programme (page does not exist)">Chernobyl Recovery and Development Programme</a>. In June 2011, she was named one of the "30 Legends of Women's Tennis: Past, Present and Future" by <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> and in March 2012 was named one of the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=100_Greatest_of_All_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="100 Greatest of All Time (page does not exist)">100 Greatest of All Time</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tennis_Channel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tennis Channel (page does not exist)">Tennis Channel</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<p>Maria Sharapova was born on April 19, 1987 in <a href="/wiki/Nyagan" title="Nyagan">Nyagan</a>, Soviet Union. Her parents, Yuri and Elena, are from <a href="/wiki/Gomel" title="Gomel">Gomel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>. Concerned about the regional effects of the 1986 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chernobyl_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chernobyl disaster (page does not exist)">Chernobyl nuclear accident</a>, they left their homeland shortly before Sharapova was born.<sup id="cite_ref-ITH_2007_08_13_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ITH_2007_08_13-5">[5]</a></sup> When Sharapova was two, the family moved to <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>. There her father befriended Aleksandr Kafelnikov, whose son <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Kafelnikov" title="Yevgeny Kafelnikov">Yevgeny</a> would go on to win two Grand Slam singles titles and become Russia's first world no. 1 ranked tennis player. Aleksandr gave Sharapova her first tennis racquet at the age of four, whereupon she began practicing regularly with her father at a local park.<sup id="cite_ref-times_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-times-6">[6]</a></sup> She took her first tennis lessons with veteran Russian coach Yuri Yutkin, who was instantly impressed when he saw her play, noting her "exceptional <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hand-eye_coordination&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hand-eye coordination (page does not exist)">hand-eye coordination</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-Article_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Article-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the age of six, Sharapova attended a tennis clinic in Moscow run by <a href="/wiki/Martina_Navratilova" title="Martina Navratilova">Martina Navratilova</a>, who recommended professional training at the <a href="/wiki/Nick_Bollettieri" title="Nick Bollettieri">Nick Bollettieri Tennis Academy</a> in Florida, which had previously trained players such as <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Anna_Kournikova" title="Anna Kournikova">Anna Kournikova</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-times_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-times-6">[6]</a></sup> With money tight, Yuri borrowed the sum that would enable him and his daughter, neither of whom could speak English, to travel to the United States, which they finally did in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-Article_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Article-7">[7]</a></sup> Visa restrictions prevented Sharapova's mother from joining them for two years.<sup id="cite_ref-ITH_2007_08_13_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ITH_2007_08_13-5">[5]</a></sup> Arriving in Florida with savings of US$700,<sup id="cite_ref-Article_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Article-7">[7]</a></sup> Sharapova's father took various low-paying jobs, including dishwashing, to fund her lessons until she was old enough to be admitted to the academy. In 1995, she was signed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=IMG_(business)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IMG (business) (page does not exist)">IMG</a>, who agreed to pay the annual tuition fee of $35,000 for Sharapova to stay at the academy, allowing her to finally enroll at the age of 9.<sup id="cite_ref-times_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-times-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tennis_career">Tennis career</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Juniors_and_early_career">Juniors and early career</span></h3>
<p>Sharapova first hit the tennis scene in November 2000, when she won the Eddie Herr International Junior Tennis Championships in the girls' 16 division at the age of just 13.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> She was then given a special distinction, the Rising Star Award, which is awarded only to players of exceptional promise.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>  Sharapova made her professional debut in 2001 on her 14th birthday on April 19, and played her first WTA tournament at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Life_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Life Open (page does not exist)">Pacific Life Open</a> in 2002, winning a match before losing to <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a>. Due to restrictions on how many professional events she could play, Sharapova went to hone her game in junior tournaments, where she reached the finals of the girls' singles events at the Australian Open and Wimbledon in 2002. She was the youngest girl ever to reach the final of the Australian Open junior championship at 14 years and 9 months.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova reached no. 6 in the <a href="/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation" title="International Tennis Federation">ITF</a> junior world singles ranking on October 21, 2002. In all, she won three junior singles tournaments and was runner-up at five, including two junior Grand Slam events. Her win-loss record in junior competition was 47–9.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p><u>Junior Grand Slam results:</u><br />
Australian Open: F (<a href="/wiki/2002_Australian_Open" title="2002 Australian Open">2002</a>)<br />
French Open: 3R (<a href="/wiki/2002_French_Open" title="2002 French Open">2002</a>)<br />
Wimbledon: F (<a href="/wiki/2002_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2002 Wimbledon Championships">2002</a>)<br />
US Open: 2R (<a href="/w/index.php?title=2001_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2001 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">2001</a>)
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2003:_First_tournament_titles">2003: First tournament titles</span></h3>
<p>From 2003, Sharapova played a full season and made a rapid climb into the top 50 by the end of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> She made her debuts at both the <a href="/wiki/2003_Australian_Open" title="2003 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2003_French_Open" title="2003 French Open">French Open</a>, but failed to win a match in either. Then, as a wildcard at <a href="/wiki/2003_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2003 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, she defeated 11th seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jelena_Doki%C4%87&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jelena Dokić (page does not exist)">Jelena Dokić</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> her first win over a top-20 player, to reach the fourth round, where she lost in three sets to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Svetlana_Kuznetsova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Svetlana Kuznetsova (page does not exist)">Svetlana Kuznetsova</a>.
</p><p>By the end of September, Sharapova had already captured her first WTA title at a smaller event, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japan Open Tennis Championships (page does not exist)">Japan Open Tennis Championships</a>, before winning her second in her final tournament of the season, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bell_Challenge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bell Challenge (page does not exist)">Bell Challenge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> To cap off her first full season as a professional, she was awarded the WTA Newcomer of the Year honor.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2004:_Winning_Wimbledon">2004: Winning Wimbledon</span></h3>
<p>Sharapova was defeated in the third round of the <a href="/wiki/2004_Australian_Open" title="2004 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> by sixth seed <a href="/wiki/Anastasia_Myskina" title="Anastasia Myskina">Anastasia Myskina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> The highlight of the remainder of her spring hard-court season was a run to the semifinals at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2004_Kroger_St._Jude_International_and_the_Cellular_South_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2004 Kroger St. Jude International and the Cellular South Cup (page does not exist)">Cellular South Cup</a>, where she ultimately lost to eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Vera_Zvonareva" title="Vera Zvonareva">Vera Zvonareva</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_at_Wimbledon_(2004).jpg" title="File:Maria Sharapova at Wimbledon (2004).jpg">File:Maria Sharapova at Wimbledon (2004).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova at Wimbledon</div></div></div>
<p>During the spring clay-court season, Sharapova entered the top 20 on the WTA world rankings as a result of reaching the third round of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qatar_Telecom_German_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qatar Telecom German Open (page does not exist)">Qatar Telecom German Open</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Internazionali BNL d'Italia (page does not exist)">Internazionali BNL d'Italia</a>, both of which were Tier I events. At the latter event, she defeated a player ranked in the top 10 for the first time with a straight-sets win over world no.&#160;10 and <a href="/w/index.php?title=2004_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2004 French Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2004 French Open</a> finalist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elena_Dementieva&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elena Dementieva (page does not exist)">Elena Dementieva</a>. Later that clay-court season, she went on to make the quarterfinals of a Grand Slam for the first time at the <a href="/wiki/2004_French_Open" title="2004 French Open">French Open</a>, losing there to <a href="/wiki/Paola_Su%C3%A1rez" title="Paola Suárez">Paola Suárez</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova won the third title of her career at the <a href="/wiki/2004_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2004 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a> warm-up <a href="/w/index.php?title=DFS_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DFS Classic (page does not exist)">DFS Classic</a>, defeating <a href="/wiki/Tatiana_Golovin" title="Tatiana Golovin">Tatiana Golovin</a> in the final. Seeded 13th and aged 17 at Wimbledon, she reached her first Grand Slam semifinal by defeating <a href="/wiki/Ai_Sugiyama" title="Ai Sugiyama">Ai Sugiyama</a>. There, she defeated fifth seed and former champion <a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Davenport" title="Lindsay Davenport">Lindsay Davenport</a>. In the final, Sharapova upset top seed and defending champion <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> to win her first Grand Slam singles title, and become the third-youngest woman to win the Wimbledon title, behind only <a href="/wiki/Lottie_Dod" title="Lottie Dod">Lottie Dod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a>. Sharapova also became the second Russian woman (after <a href="/wiki/Anastasia_Myskina" title="Anastasia Myskina">Anastasia Myskina</a> had won the year's previous major at <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">Roland Garros</a>) to win a Grand Slam singles title. The victory was hailed by the media as "the most stunning upset in memory",<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> with other writers commenting on her arrival as a serious challenger to the <a href="/wiki/Williams_sisters" title="Williams sisters">Williams'</a> dominance at Wimbledon.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> She entered the top 10 in the rankings for the first time as a result of the win.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following her Wimbledon win, attention and interest in Sharapova in the media greatly increased, a rise in popularity dubbed "Maria Mania."<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> She won three of six matches in her preparations for the <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>. At the US Open itself, she reached the third round, before being eliminated by <a href="/wiki/Mary_Pierce" title="Mary Pierce">Mary Pierce</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> In order to regain confidence, Sharapova played and won consecutive titles in Asia in the fall, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hansol_Korea_Open_Tennis_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hansol Korea Open Tennis Championships (page does not exist)">Hansol Korea Open Tennis Championships</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japan Open Tennis Championships (page does not exist)">Japan Open Tennis Championships</a>.
</p><p>In October, Sharapova defeated <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus Williams</a> en route to making the final of a Tier I event for the first time at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zurich_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zurich Open (page does not exist)">Zurich Open</a>, losing in the final to <a href="/wiki/Alicia_Molik" title="Alicia Molik">Alicia Molik</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> She then made her debut at the year-ending <a href="/wiki/WTA_Tour_Championships" title="WTA Tour Championships">WTA Tour Championships</a>. There, she won two of her three round-robin matches (including a win over US Open champion <a href="/w/index.php?title=Svetlana_Kuznetsova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Svetlana Kuznetsova (page does not exist)">Svetlana Kuznetsova</a>) in order to advance to the semifinals, where she defeated Myskina. In the final, she defeated Serena Williams, after trailing 4–0 in the final set.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2005:_World_no..C2.A01">2005: World no.&#160;1</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_Indian_Wells_2005.jpg" title="File:Maria Sharapova Indian Wells 2005.jpg">File:Maria Sharapova Indian Wells 2005.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova at <a href="/wiki/Indian_Wells_Masters" title="Indian Wells Masters">Indian Wells</a> in 2005</div></div></div>
<p>Sharapova started the year at the <a href="/wiki/2005_Australian_Open" title="2005 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, where she defeated fifth seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Svetlana_Kuznetsova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Svetlana Kuznetsova (page does not exist)">Svetlana Kuznetsova</a> to reach the second Grand Slam semifinal of her career. Sharapova held match points in the third set of her semifinal match, before losing to eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a>. In February, Sharapova won back-to-back tournaments, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Toray_Pan_Pacific_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Toray Pan Pacific Open (page does not exist)">Toray Pan Pacific Open</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qatar_Total_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qatar Total Open (page does not exist)">Qatar Total Open</a>, allowing her to reach number 3 in the world rankings for the first time.
</p><p>In the semifinals of the Tier I <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Life_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Life Open (page does not exist)">Pacific Life Open</a>, Sharapova was defeated by <a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Davenport" title="Lindsay Davenport">Lindsay Davenport</a>, the first time she had failed to win a game in a match.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> She defeated former world no.&#160;1 players <a href="/wiki/Justine_Henin" title="Justine Henin">Justine Henin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus Williams</a> to reach the final at the Tier I <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ-100_Open" title="NASDAQ-100 Open" class="mw-redirect">NASDAQ-100 Open</a>, where she lost to <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova made the semifinals of a clay-court tournament for the first time at the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Open_(tennis)" title="Italian Open (tennis)">Italian Open</a>, where she lost to <a href="/wiki/Patty_Schnyder" title="Patty Schnyder">Patty Schnyder</a>. Sharapova would have become world no.&#160;1 for the first time had she won the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> Sharapova then reached the quarterfinals of the <a href="/wiki/2005_French_Open" title="2005 French Open">French Open</a> for the second consecutive year, before losing to eventual champion Henin.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> On grass, Sharapova won her third title of the year when she successfully defended her title at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=DFS_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DFS Classic (page does not exist)">DFS Classic</a>, defeating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jelena Janković (page does not exist)">Jelena Janković</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> As the defending champion at <a href="/wiki/2005_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2005 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, Sharapova reached the semifinals without dropping a set and losing a service game just once, extending her winning streak on grass to 24 matches. However, she was then beaten by eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus Williams</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova had far fewer points to defend, and so she became the first Russian woman to hold the world no.&#160;1 ranking on August 22, 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-wtacareer_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtacareer-33">[33]</a></sup> Her reign lasted only one week, however, as Davenport reclaimed the top ranking after winning the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pilot_Pen_Tennis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pilot Pen Tennis (page does not exist)">Pilot Pen Tennis</a> tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-wtacareer_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtacareer-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>As the top seed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2005_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2005 US Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">US Open</a>, Sharapova lost in the semifinals to <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> meaning she had lost to the eventual champion in every Grand Slam of the season. However, she once again leapfrogged Davenport to take the world no.&#160;1 ranking on September 12, 2005. She retained it for six weeks, but after playing few tournaments while injured, she again relinquished the ranking to Davenport.<sup id="cite_ref-wtacareer_33-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtacareer-33">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> To conclude the year, Sharapova failed to defend her title at the year-end <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sony_Ericsson_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sony Ericsson Championships (page does not exist)">Sony Ericsson Championships</a> in Los Angeles, defeating Davenport in one of her round-robin matches, but ultimately losing in the semifinals to eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Am%C3%A9lie_Mauresmo" title="Amélie Mauresmo">Amélie Mauresmo</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2006:_US_Open_champion">2006: US Open champion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MariaSharapova.JPG" title="File:MariaSharapova.JPG">File:MariaSharapova.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova celebrating after winning the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">2006 US Open</a></div></div></div>
<p>Sharapova started 2006 by losing in the semifinals of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 Australian Open (page does not exist)">Australian Open</a> in three sets to Henin,<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> also losing a rematch several weeks later at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dubai_Tennis_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dubai Tennis Championships (page does not exist)">Dubai Tennis Championships</a>, having defeated former world no.&#160;1 <a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a> and world no.&#160;3 <a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Davenport" title="Lindsay Davenport">Lindsay Davenport</a> in earlier rounds of the tournament. Sharapova claimed her first title in nine months at the Tier I tournament in Indian Wells, defeating Hingis in the semifinals and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elena_Dementieva&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elena Dementieva (page does not exist)">Elena Dementieva</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> She reached the final in <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_NASDAQ-100_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 NASDAQ-100 Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">Miami</a> before losing to Kuznetsova.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova returned for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 French Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">French Open</a>. There, after saving match points in defeating <a href="/wiki/Mashona_Washington" title="Mashona Washington">Mashona Washington</a> in the first round, she was eliminated by <a href="/wiki/Dinara_Safina" title="Dinara Safina">Dinara Safina</a> in the fourth round.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> On grass, Sharapova was unsuccessful in her attempt to win in Birmingham for the third consecutive year, losing in the semifinals to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jamea_Jackson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jamea Jackson (page does not exist)">Jamea Jackson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> Despite that, she was among the title favorites at <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_Wimbledon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 Wimbledon (page does not exist)">Wimbledon</a>, where the eventual champion Mauresmo ended up beating her in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova claimed her second title of the year at the Tier I <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acura_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acura Classic (page does not exist)">Acura Classic</a>, defeating Clijsters for the first time in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> As the third seed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">US Open</a>, Sharapova defeated top seed Mauresmo for the first time in the semifinals,<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> and then followed up by beating second seed <a href="/wiki/Justine_Henin" title="Justine Henin">Justine Henin</a> to win her second Grand Slam singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>That autumn, Sharapova won titles in back-to-back weeks at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zurich_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zurich Open (page does not exist)">Zurich Open</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Generali_Ladies_Linz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Generali Ladies Linz (page does not exist)">Generali Ladies Linz</a>. By winning all three of her round-robin matches at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_WTA_Tour_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 WTA Tour Championships – Singles (page does not exist)">WTA Tour Championships</a>, she extended her win streak to 19 matches, before it was snapped in the semifinals by eventual champion Henin.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Sharapova would have finished the season as world no.&#160;1 had she won the event. As it was, she finished ranked world no.&#160;2, her best year-end finish yet.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2007:_Shoulder_injury_and_fall_out_of_the_top_5">2007: Shoulder injury and fall out of the top 5</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_US_Open_2007.jpg" title="File:Maria Sharapova US Open 2007.jpg">File:Maria Sharapova US Open 2007.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007 Australian Open (page does not exist)">2007 Australian Open</a></div></div></div>
<p>Sharapova was the top seed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007 Australian Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">Australian Open</a> due to top-ranked <a href="/wiki/Justine_Henin" title="Justine Henin">Justine Henin</a>'s withdrawal. After being two points away from defeat in the first round against <a href="/w/index.php?title=Camille_Pin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Camille Pin (page does not exist)">Camille Pin</a>, she went on to reach the final of the tournament for the first time, but was routed there by <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> who was ranked world no.&#160;81 at the time. After reaching the final, Sharapova recaptured the world no.&#160;1 ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-wtacareer_33-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtacareer-33">[33]</a></sup> She held it for seven weeks, surrendering it back to Henin after failing to defend her title at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Life_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Life Open (page does not exist)">Pacific Life Open</a>, instead losing in the fourth round to <a href="/wiki/Vera_Zvonareva" title="Vera Zvonareva">Vera Zvonareva</a> after struggling with a hamstring injury.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> The following fortnight, she defeated <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus Williams</a> in the third round of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sony_Ericsson_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sony Ericsson Open (page does not exist)">Sony Ericsson Open</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> before suffering another defeat to Serena Williams.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>A shoulder injury forced Sharapova to miss most of the clay-court season for the second consecutive year, resulting in her only tune-up for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007_French_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007 French Open (page does not exist)">French Open</a> being the <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C4%B0stanbul_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="İstanbul Cup (page does not exist)">İstanbul Cup</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> where she lost in the semifinals to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aravane_Reza%C3%AF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aravane Rezaï (page does not exist)">Aravane Reza&#239;</a>. She reached the semifinals of the French Open for the first time in her career, before losing to <a href="/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic" title="Ana Ivanovic">Ana Ivanovic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> On grass, Sharapova was runner-up to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jelena Janković (page does not exist)">Jelena Janković</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=DFS_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DFS Classic (page does not exist)">DFS Classic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Following that, she experienced her earliest Wimbledon loss since 2003 by losing in the fourth round to eventual champion Venus Williams.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova clinched the <a href="/w/index.php?title=US_Open_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="US Open Series (page does not exist)">US Open Series</a> by defending her title at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acura_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acura Classic (page does not exist)">Acura Classic</a>, her only championship of the year, and reaching the semifinals in Los Angeles.<sup id="cite_ref-wtacareer_33-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtacareer-33">[33]</a></sup> In her <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">US Open</a> title defense, Sharapova was upset in her third-round match to 30th seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agnieszka_Radwa%C5%84ska&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agnieszka Radwańska (page does not exist)">Agnieszka Radwańska</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-radwanska_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-radwanska-54">[54]</a></sup> making it her earliest exit at a Grand Slam singles tournament since the <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">2004 US Open</a>, where she lost in the same round.<sup id="cite_ref-wtacareer_33-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtacareer-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the US Open loss, Sharapova did not play again until the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kremlin_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kremlin Cup (page does not exist)">Kremlin Cup</a> in October, where she lost her opening match to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victoria_Azarenka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victoria Azarenka (page does not exist)">Victoria Azarenka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Shortly after this, she fell out of the top 5 in the world rankings for the first time since 2004. She qualified for the eight-woman year-end <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007_WTA_Tour_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007 WTA Tour Championships (page does not exist)">Sony Ericsson Championships</a> because of a withdrawal by Venus Williams before the start of the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-wtacareer_33-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtacareer-33">[33]</a></sup> Despite having not previously won a match in two months, Sharapova topped her round-robin group at the tournament, after winning all three of her matches, defeating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Svetlana_Kuznetsova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Svetlana Kuznetsova (page does not exist)">Svetlana Kuznetsova</a>, Ana Ivanovic, and <a href="/wiki/Daniela_Hantuchov%C3%A1" title="Daniela Hantuchová">Daniela Hantuchová</a>. She then defeated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anna_Chakvetadze&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anna Chakvetadze (page does not exist)">Anna Chakvetadze</a> in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> In the final, she lost to world no.&#160;1 Henin in a match that lasted 3 hours and 24 minutes. Sharapova reached the top five again to end the year.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2008:_Australian_Open_champion_and_recurrence_of_shoulder_injury">2008: Australian Open champion and recurrence of shoulder injury</span></h3>
<p>Sharapova was seeded fifth at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Australian Open (page does not exist)">Australian Open</a>, but was not considered a favorite. Nevertheless, she defeated former world no.&#160;1 <a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Davenport" title="Lindsay Davenport">Lindsay Davenport</a> in the second round, and then world no.&#160;1 Henin in the quarterfinals,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> ending the latter's 32-match winning streak.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> She proceeded to the finals by defeating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jelena Janković (page does not exist)">Jelena Janković</a> in the semifinals, and defeated <a href="/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic" title="Ana Ivanovic">Ana Ivanovic</a> in the final to win her third Grand Slam title, having not dropped a set all tournament.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_in_Russian_team_uniform.JPG" title="File:Maria Sharapova in Russian team uniform.JPG">File:Maria Sharapova in Russian team uniform.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova playing at the Pacific Life Open in 2008</div></div></div>
<p>After the Australian Open, Sharapova extended her winning streak to 18 matches. This run encompassed two wins including at the Tier I <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Qatar_Total_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Qatar Total Open (page does not exist)">Qatar Total Open</a>. Her winning streak was ended in the semifinals of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Pacific_Life_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Pacific Life Open (page does not exist)">Pacific Life Open</a> by Kuznetsova. In April, Sharapova won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Bausch_%26_Lomb_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Bausch &amp; Lomb Championships (page does not exist)">Bausch &amp; Lomb Championships</a>, having survived her longest-ever match, at 3 hours and 26 minutes long, in the third round against <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anabel_Medina_Garrigues&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anabel Medina Garrigues (page does not exist)">Anabel Medina Garrigues</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-epicbattle_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-epicbattle-60">[60]</a></sup> The following week, at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Family_Circle_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Family Circle Cup (page does not exist)">Family Circle Cup</a>, she lost in the quarterfinals to <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a>, her fourth consecutive loss to the American.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May, Sharapova regained the world no.&#160;1 ranking because of Henin's sudden retirement from professional tennis and request to the <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Tennis_Association" title="Women's Tennis Association">WTA</a> that her own ranking be removed immediately.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> As the top-seeded player at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 French Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">French Open</a> Sharapova was within two points<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> of being knocked out by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evgeniya_Rodina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evgeniya Rodina (page does not exist)">Evgeniya Rodina</a> in the first round, before eventually winning.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> As a result of losing to eventual finalist <a href="/wiki/Dinara_Safina" title="Dinara Safina">Dinara Safina</a> in the fourth round (after serving for the match),<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> she relinquished her no.&#160;1 ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Her dip in form continued at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wimbledon_2008&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wimbledon 2008 (page does not exist)">Wimbledon</a>, where she lost in the second round to world no.&#160;154 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alla_Kudryavtseva&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alla Kudryavtseva (page does not exist)">Alla Kudryavtseva</a>. This was her earliest loss at Wimbledon, and at any Grand Slam in almost five years.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova withdrew from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rogers_Cup_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rogers Cup (tennis) (page does not exist)">Rogers Cup</a> tournament in August following a shoulder injury.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_resonance_imaging" title="Magnetic resonance imaging">MRI</a> scan revealed that she had been suffering from a <a href="/wiki/Rotator_cuff_tear" title="Rotator cuff tear">rotator cuff tear</a> since April, forcing her out of all tournaments for the rest of the season, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tennis_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics (page does not exist)">Beijing Olympics</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">US Open</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_WTA_Tour_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 WTA Tour Championships (page does not exist)">WTA Tour Championships</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> In spite of that, she still finished the year ranked world no.&#160;9. In October, after a failed attempt to rehabilitate the shoulder, Sharapova had surgery to repair the tear.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2009:_Shoulder_surgery_and_rehabilitation">2009: Shoulder surgery and rehabilitation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_at_2009_Roland_Garros,_Paris,_France.jpg" title="File:Maria Sharapova at 2009 Roland Garros, Paris, France.jpg">File:Maria Sharapova at 2009 Roland Garros, Paris, France.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova made the quarterfinals of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_French_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 French Open (page does not exist)">French Open</a>, her best Grand Slam performance of 2009</div></div></div>
<p>Sharapova did not attempt to defend her <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 Australian Open (page does not exist)">Australian Open</a> title, as she continued to recover from surgery.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> She returned to the sport in March, in the doubles tournament at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Doubles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 BNP Paribas Open – Women's Doubles (page does not exist)">BNP Paribas Open</a>, but she and partner <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elena_Vesnina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elena Vesnina (page does not exist)">Elena Vesnina</a> lost in the first round. After this, Sharapova withdrew from further singles tournaments, resulting in her standing in the world rankings being severely affected. She dropped out of the top 100 for the first time in six years in May, the nadir being world no.&#160;126.<sup id="cite_ref-wtatennis_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtatennis-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>Playing her first singles tournament in nearly ten months, Sharapova made the quarterfinals of the clay-court <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_Warsaw_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 Warsaw Open – Singles (page does not exist)">Warsaw Open</a> in May, losing to finalist <a href="/wiki/Alona_Bondarenko" title="Alona Bondarenko">Alona Bondarenko</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> The following week, in her first Grand Slam appearance since her surgery, she reached the quarterfinals of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 French Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">French Open</a>, before her run was ended by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominika_Cibulkov%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominika Cibulková (page does not exist)">Dominika Cibulková</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the summer grass-court season, Sharapova played in <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_Aegon_Classic_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 Aegon Classic – Singles (page does not exist)">Birmingham</a>, losing in the semifinals to Li Na.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> Sharapova then played at <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_Wimbledon_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 Wimbledon Championships (page does not exist)">Wimbledon</a> as the 24th seed. She was upset in the second round by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gisela_Dulko&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gisela Dulko (page does not exist)">Gisela Dulko</a> in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova enjoyed considerable success in the summer months, reaching the quarterfinals at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_Bank_of_the_West_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 Bank of the West Classic (page does not exist)">Bank of the West Classic</a>, the semifinals at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_LA_Women%27s_Tennis_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 LA Women's Tennis Championships (page does not exist)">LA Women's Tennis Championships</a>, and finishing runner-up at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_Rogers_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 Rogers Cup (page does not exist)">Rogers Cup</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elena_Dementieva&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elena Dementieva (page does not exist)">Elena Dementieva</a>. At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">2009 US Open</a>, Sharapova was seeded 29th. She found her way into the third round, defeating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tsvetana_Pironkova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tsvetana Pironkova (page does not exist)">Tsvetana Pironkova</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christina_McHale&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christina McHale (page does not exist)">Christina McHale</a> all in straight sets. She was stunned in the third round by American teenager <a href="/w/index.php?title=Melanie_Oudin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Melanie Oudin (page does not exist)">Melanie Oudin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> It was the second time in Sharapova's career that she lost to a teenager at a <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a>, having lost to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agnieszka_Radwa%C5%84ska&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agnieszka Radwańska (page does not exist)">Agnieszka Radwańska</a> during the same event in 2007. The loss made Sharapova's ranking go down to no.&#160;32.<sup id="cite_ref-wtatennis_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtatennis-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>The final stretch of the season brought Sharapova her first title of the year in <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_Toray_Pan_Pacific_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 Toray Pan Pacific Open (page does not exist)">Tokyo</a>, after opponent <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jelena Janković (page does not exist)">Jelena Janković</a> retired after being down 2–5 to Sharapova in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> By virtue of that result, she was the recipient of a bye at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_China_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 China Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">China Open</a>, but failed to capitalize on it, losing to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peng_Shuai&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peng Shuai (page does not exist)">Peng Shuai</a> in the third round.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> She ultimately finished the season at world no.&#160;14, having improved from no.&#160;126 when she started her comeback from injury.<sup id="cite_ref-wtatennis_72-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtatennis-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2010:_Struggles_with_form">2010: Struggles with form</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_practicing_at_Bank_of_the_West_Classic_2010-07-25_3.JPG" title="File:Maria Sharapova practicing at Bank of the West Classic 2010-07-25 3.JPG">File:Maria Sharapova practicing at Bank of the West Classic 2010-07-25 3.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova practising at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_the_West_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bank of the West Classic (page does not exist)">Bank of the West Classic</a> in 2010</div></div></div>
<p>After playing two exhibition tournaments in Asia, Sharapova officially began her season at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Australian Open (page does not exist)">Australian Open</a>, where she was upset in her first-round match against <a href="/wiki/Maria_Kirilenko" title="Maria Kirilenko">Maria Kirilenko</a>. The loss meant that for the first time since 2003, Sharapova had lost her opening match at a Grand Slam event.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> She then rebounded by winning a smaller American event, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Regions_Morgan_Keegan_Championships_and_the_Cellular_South_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Regions Morgan Keegan Championships and the Cellular South Cup (page does not exist)">Cellular South Cup</a>, her 21st career WTA title and first of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_BNP_Paribas_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 BNP Paribas Open (page does not exist)">BNP Paribas Open</a>, Sharapova lost in the third round to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zheng_Jie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zheng Jie (page does not exist)">Zheng Jie</a>, aggravating a bruised bone on her right elbow in the process, which resulted in her eventual withdrawal from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Sony_Ericsson_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Sony Ericsson Open (page does not exist)">Sony Ericsson Open</a><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Family_Circle_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Family Circle Cup (page does not exist)">Family Circle Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>Returning at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open (page does not exist)">2010 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open</a>, Sharapova lost in the first round to <a href="/wiki/Lucie_%C5%A0af%C3%A1%C5%99ov%C3%A1" title="Lucie Šafářová">Lucie Šafářová</a>. She continued her French Open preparation at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Internationaux_de_Strasbourg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Internationaux de Strasbourg (page does not exist)">Internationaux de Strasbourg</a> as a wildcard, advancing to the final, where she beat <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kristina_Barrois&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kristina Barrois (page does not exist)">Kristina Barrois</a>. This was her first title on red clay and 22nd overall title.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_French_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 French Open (page does not exist)">French Open</a>, Sharapova's brief clay season culminated with a third-round loss to four-time champion <a href="/wiki/Justine_Henin" title="Justine Henin">Justine Henin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova began her preparations for Wimbledon at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Aegon_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Aegon Classic (page does not exist)">Aegon Classic</a>. She advanced to the final for the fourth time, where she lost to <a href="/wiki/Li_Na_(tennis)" title="Li Na (tennis)">Li Na</a>. As the 16th seed at <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Wimbledon_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Wimbledon Championships (page does not exist)">Wimbledon</a>, Sharapova lost in the fourth round to world no.&#160;1 and eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a>, despite having three set points in the opening set.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> The match was seen as another encouraging performance for Sharapova, with some stating their belief that she was approaching the form that would see her contending for Grand Slams once more,<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> and Sharapova herself stating that she felt that she was "in a much better spot than I was last year."<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/w/index.php?title=US_Open_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="US Open Series (page does not exist)">US Open Series</a>, Sharapova made two straight finals, losing to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victoria_Azarenka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victoria Azarenka (page does not exist)">Victoria Azarenka</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Bank_of_the_West_Classic_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Bank of the West Classic – Singles (page does not exist)">Bank of the West Classic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> and to <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Western_%26_Southern_Financial_Group_Women%27s_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Western &amp; Southern Financial Group Women's Open – Singles (page does not exist)">Western &amp; Southern Financial Group Women's Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> In the latter match, Sharapova held three match points while leading 5–3 on Clijsters's serve late in the second set, but could not convert them. At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">U.S. Open</a>, Sharapova was the 14th seed. She made it to the fourth round, where she played top seed and 2009 finalist <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Wozniacki" title="Caroline Wozniacki">Caroline Wozniacki</a> and lost.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova's last two tournaments of the season ended in disappointment. She played in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Toray_Pan_Pacific_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Toray Pan Pacific Open – Singles (page does not exist)">Toray Pan Pacific Open</a> in Tokyo, where she was upset in the first round by 39-year-old <a href="/wiki/Kimiko_Date-Krumm" title="Kimiko Date-Krumm">Kimiko Date-Krumm</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Her last tournament of the year was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_China_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 China Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">China Open</a>, where she lost in the second round to fellow Russian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elena_Vesnina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elena Vesnina (page does not exist)">Elena Vesnina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> She ended the year at number 18 in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2011:_Return_to_top_10">2011: Return to top 10</span></h3>
<p>It was announced that Sharapova would bring in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_H%C3%B6gstedt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas Högstedt (page does not exist)">Thomas Högstedt</a> as a coach for the 2011 season, joining <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Joyce_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Joyce (tennis) (page does not exist)">Michael Joyce</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> On December 5, Sharapova won an exhibition match against world no.&#160;2 <a href="/wiki/Vera_Zvonareva" title="Vera Zvonareva">Vera Zvonareva</a> in Monterrey, Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> In Sharapova's first official Australian Open warm-up tournament at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_ASB_Classic_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 ASB Classic – Singles (page does not exist)">2011 ASB Classic</a> in Auckland, New Zealand, she was seeded first. She lost to the Hungarian veteran and eventual champion <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gr%C3%A9ta_Arn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gréta Arn (page does not exist)">Gréta Arn</a> in the quarterfinals. After the ASB Classic, Sharapova decided to take a hiatus from Joyce's coaching, despite having worked together for a number of years, including during her successful years where she became a multiple Grand Slam champion.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova participated in the first Grand Slam of the season at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Australian Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">Australian Open</a>, where she was the 14th seed, but lost to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Andrea_Petkovic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Andrea Petkovic (page does not exist)">Andrea Petkovic</a> in the fourth round.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> She also had to pull out of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Dubai_Tennis_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Dubai Tennis Championships (page does not exist)">2011 Dubai Tennis Championships</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Qatar_Ladies_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Qatar Ladies Open (page does not exist)">2011 Qatar Ladies Open</a> because of an ear infection.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> Sharapova returned to the tour in March by taking part in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_BNP_Paribas_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 BNP Paribas Open (page does not exist)">2011 BNP Paribas Open</a>, where she was seeded 16th. She defeated former world no.&#160;1 <a href="/wiki/Dinara_Safina" title="Dinara Safina">Dinara Safina</a>, in the fourth round en route to the semifinal, where she lost to world no.&#160;1 <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Wozniacki" title="Caroline Wozniacki">Caroline Wozniacki</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Sony_Ericsson_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Sony Ericsson Open (page does not exist)">2011 Sony Ericsson Open</a> in Key Biscayne, Sharapova defeated 26th seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alexandra_Dulgheru&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alexandra Dulgheru (page does not exist)">Alexandra Dulgheru</a> 3–6, 7–6<sup>6</sup>, 7–6<sup>5</sup> in the quarterfinals, lasting 3 hours and 28 minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> In the semifinals, Sharapova took her <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Australian Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">Australian Open</a> reprisal on Germany's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Andrea_Petkovic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Andrea Petkovic (page does not exist)">Andrea Petkovic</a> by defeating her. In the final, she was defeated by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victoria_Azarenka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victoria Azarenka (page does not exist)">Victoria Azarenka</a>, despite a late comeback in the second set.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> With this result, Sharapova returned to the top 10 for the first time since February 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-wtatennis_72-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtatennis-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2011_French_Open_Maria_Sharapova_.jpg" title="File:2011 French Open Maria Sharapova .jpg">File:2011 French Open Maria Sharapova .jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova at <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Roland_Garros&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Roland Garros (page does not exist)">2011 Roland Garros</a></div></div></div>
<p>During the clay-court season, Sharapova participated in <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open (page does not exist)">2011 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open</a>, where she lost to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominika_Cibulkov%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominika Cibulková (page does not exist)">Dominika Cibulková</a> in the third round, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Internazionali BNL d'Italia (page does not exist)">2011 Internazionali BNL d'Italia</a>, where she was seeded seventh. She defeated top seed Caroline Wozniacki in the semifinals and sixth seed Samantha Stosur in the final to take home the title, marking her biggest clay-court victory to date.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_French_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 French Open (page does not exist)">2011 French Open</a>, Sharapova was seeded seventh. She defeated French wildcard <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caroline_Garcia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caroline Garcia (page does not exist)">Caroline Garcia</a> in the second round, despite trailing 3–6, 1–4, before winning the last 11 games of the match. In the quarterfinals, she defeated 15th seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Andrea_Petkovic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Andrea Petkovic (page does not exist)">Andrea Petkovic</a>, marking her first Grand Slam semifinal since her comeback from the career-threatening shoulder injury. She then lost to sixth seed and eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Li_Na_(tennis)" title="Li Na (tennis)">Li Na</a>, in the semifinals, ending her clay season with a win-loss record of 12–2.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Wimbledon_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Wimbledon Championships (page does not exist)">2011 Wimbledon Championships</a>, Sharapova had not dropped a set entering the final, before losing to eighth seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Petra_Kvitov%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Petra Kvitová (page does not exist)">Petra Kvitová</a> in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> This marked her first final in over three years at a Grand Slam event. Sharapova started her summer hard-court season at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Bank_of_the_West_Classic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Bank of the West Classic (page does not exist)">2011 Bank of the West Classic</a> in <a href="/wiki/Stanford,_California" title="Stanford, California">Stanford, California</a>. In a highly anticipated match, Sharapova lost to the eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> in the quarterfinals.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> In her next event at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Rogers_Cup_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Rogers Cup – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2011 Rogers Cup</a> in Toronto, Canada, Sharapova lost to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Galina_Voskoboeva&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Galina Voskoboeva (page does not exist)">Galina Voskoboeva</a> in the third round, marking her 100th career loss.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova then contested the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Western &amp; Southern Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2011 Western &amp; Southern Open</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cincinnati&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cincinnati (page does not exist)">Cincinnati</a>, Ohio. As the fourth seed, she received a bye into the second round. On the way to her fourth final of the year, she beat <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anastasia_Rodionova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anastasia Rodionova (page does not exist)">Anastasia Rodionova</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> 14th seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Svetlana_Kuznetsova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Svetlana Kuznetsova (page does not exist)">Svetlana Kuznetsova</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> tenth seed Samantha Stosur,<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> and 2nd seed Vera Zvonareva.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> In the final, she defeated fellow former world no.&#160;1 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jelena Janković (page does not exist)">Jelena Janković</a>, in 2 hours and 49 minutes, making it the longest WTA tour final of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> She subsequently moved up to world no.&#160;4, her highest ranking since August 2008 and the highest since her comeback from her shoulder injury.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova entered the <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, where she was seeded third. She beat British <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heather_Watson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heather Watson (page does not exist)">Heather Watson</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anastasiya_Yakimova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anastasiya Yakimova (page does not exist)">Anastasiya Yakimova</a>, to reach the third round. She was then upset by <a href="/wiki/Flavia_Pennetta" title="Flavia Pennetta">Flavia Pennetta</a>. However, because of the fall of <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a> and Vera Zvonareva in the rankings, Sharapova climbed to world no.&#160;2.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Sharapova's next tournament was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Toray_Pan_Pacific_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Toray Pan Pacific Open (page does not exist)">2011 Toray Pan Pacific Open</a> in Tokyo, Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> As second seed, she received a bye into the second round, where she beat <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tamarine_Tanasugarn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tamarine Tanasugarn (page does not exist)">Tamarine Tanasugarn</a>. She then beat 13th seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Julia_G%C3%B6rges&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Julia Görges (page does not exist)">Julia Görges</a>, before retiring against Petra Kvitová in the quarterfinal, 3–4, after slipping on the baseline, suffering an ankle injury. This also forced her to withdraw from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_China_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 China Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">2011 China Open</a> the following week. Sharapova then flew to Istanbul to prepare for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_WTA_Tour_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 WTA Tour Championships (page does not exist)">2011 WTA Tour Championships</a>, her first time qualifying since 2007. During the WTA Tour Championships, Sharapova withdrew during the round-robin stage after defeats against Samantha Stosur and <a href="/wiki/Li_Na_(tennis)" title="Li Na (tennis)">Li Na</a>, as a result of the ankle injury she had suffered in Tokyo.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Sharapova ended the year as no. 4 in the world, her first top-10 finish since 2008 and first top-5 finish since 2007.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2012:_Return_to_no..C2.A01.2C_Career_Grand_Slam_and_Olympic_silver_medal">2012: Return to no.&#160;1, Career Grand Slam and Olympic silver medal</span></h3>
<p>Sharapova withdrew from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Brisbane_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Brisbane International (page does not exist)">2012 Brisbane International</a> because of her ongoing ankle injury.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Her first tournament of the season was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Australian Open (page does not exist)">2012 Australian Open</a>, where she was seeded fourth. Sharapova advanced to the final round conceding five games, defeating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gisela_Dulko&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gisela Dulko (page does not exist)">Gisela Dulko</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jamie_Hampton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jamie Hampton (page does not exist)">Jamie Hampton</a>, and 30th seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Angelique_Kerber&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Angelique Kerber (page does not exist)">Angelique Kerber</a>, compatriot <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ekaterina_Makarova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ekaterina Makarova (page does not exist)">Ekaterina Makarova</a> and world no.&#160;2 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Petra_Kvitov%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Petra Kvitová (page does not exist)">Petra Kvitová</a>. She lost to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victoria_Azarenka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victoria Azarenka (page does not exist)">Victoria Azarenka</a> in two sets. As a result her ranking improved to world no.&#160;3. She then played in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Open_GDF_Suez&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Open GDF Suez (page does not exist)">Paris</a>, where she lost in the quarterfinals to eventual champion Angelique Kerber. As a result her ranking improved to world no.&#160;2.
</p><p>At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 BNP Paribas Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">Indian Wells</a>, after battling for over three hours, Sharapova defeated compatriot <a href="/wiki/Maria_Kirilenko" title="Maria Kirilenko">Maria Kirilenko</a> to set up a semifinal meeting with <a href="/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic" title="Ana Ivanovic">Ana Ivanovic</a>.
