Sharapova advanced to the final after Ivanovic retired due to a hip injury.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In the final, she played world no.&#160;1 Victoria Azarenka in a rematch of the Australian Open final, but lost again in straight sets. Sharapova's next tournament was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Sony_Ericsson_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Sony Ericsson Open (page does not exist)">2012 Sony Ericsson Open</a>, where she was seeded 2nd and received a bye. In the final, Sharapova lost in straight sets to 5th seeded <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agnieszka_Radwa%C5%84ska&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agnieszka Radwańska (page does not exist)">Agnieszka Radwańska</a>. This was her third loss of the year in finals out of four tournaments played so far. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Porsche_Tennis_Grand_Prix_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Porsche Tennis Grand Prix – Singles (page does not exist)">Porsche Tennis Grand Prix</a> in Stuttgart, Sharapova was seeded second. She had a bye in the first round, and advanced to the third round after <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aliz%C3%A9_Cornet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alizé Cornet (page does not exist)">Alizé Cornet</a> retired in the second set. She won her first title of the year in Stuttgart after defeating world number one Victoria Azarenka. In doing so, Sharapova defeated three current Grand Slam title holders to win the tournament. Sharapova then played on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Mutua_Madrid_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Mutua Madrid Open (page does not exist)">2012 Mutua Madrid Open</a>, a premier mandatory event. In the third round, Sharapova's opponent <a href="/wiki/Lucie_%C5%A0af%C3%A1%C5%99ov%C3%A1" title="Lucie Šafářová">Lucie Šafářová</a> was unable to compete and withdrew from the tournament, earning Sharapova a walkover into the quarterfinals.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> She was then beaten by eventual champion <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> in straight sets.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Victoria_Azarenka,_Serena_Williams_and_Maria_Sharapova_with_medals_2012.jpg" title="File:Victoria Azarenka, Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova with medals 2012.jpg">File:Victoria Azarenka, Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova with medals 2012.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova carried the flag for Russia during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony (page does not exist)">opening ceremony of the 2012 Summer Olympics</a>. She lost in the final to Serena Williams to take the silver medal.</div></div></div>
<p>As the defending champion and second seed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Internazionali BNL d'Italia (page does not exist)">Italian Open</a>, Sharapova had a bye in the first round. In the semifinals, Sharapova defeated Angelique Kerber to advance to the final for the second year in a row. In the final, Sharapova saved match point for a 2 hour 52 minute win over <a href="/wiki/Li_Na_(tennis)" title="Li Na (tennis)">Li Na</a> for her 26th career title.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> This marked the fourth time Sharapova had successfully defended a title.
</p><p>Sharapova was seeded second at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_French_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 French Open (page does not exist)">French Open</a>, where she defeated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alexandra_Cadan%C8%9Bu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alexandra Cadanțu (page does not exist)">Alexandra Cadanțu</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Petra_Kvitov%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Petra Kvitová (page does not exist)">Petra Kvitová</a> on her way to the finals, allowing her to regain the world no.&#160;1 ranking. In the final, she defeated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sara_Errani&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sara Errani (page does not exist)">Sara Errani</a> for her first French Open title. Sharapova became only the tenth woman to complete a Career Grand Slam with the French Open victory.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> During the tournament, Sharapova was also asked by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_Olympic_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian Olympic Committee (page does not exist)">Russian Olympic Committee</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_flag_bearers_for_Russia_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of flag bearers for Russia at the Olympics (page does not exist)">carry the Russian flag</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">Olympic Games</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova then extended her win streak to 15 matches when she competed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">Wimbledon Championships</a> as the top seed there for the first time in her career. However, she was upset in the fourth round by 15th-seeded <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sabine_Lisicki&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sabine Lisicki (page does not exist)">Sabine Lisicki</a>, whom she beat in last year's semifinals. As a result, she lost her no. 1 ranking to Victoria Azarenka.
</p><p>She played in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics (page does not exist)">2012 Summer Olympic Games</a> in London, her first Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> In the quarterfinals, Sharapova defeated fellow former no. 1 <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a> to advance to the semifinals, where she faced her compatriot, <a href="/wiki/Maria_Kirilenko" title="Maria Kirilenko">Maria Kirilenko</a>. Sharapova defeated Kirilenko to reach the Olympic final, where she lost to Serena Williams,<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> marking her worst defeat to the American. With this performance, Sharapova overtook Agnieszka Radwańska as world no. 2.
</p><p>Sharapova was seeded third at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 US Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">US Open</a>, but had no hard-court tune-ups after the Olympics due to a stomach virus.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> In the fourth round, Petrova took it to a third set and was winning until a rain delay. After the delay, Sharapova came back to win. In the quarterfinals she faced <a href="/wiki/Marion_Bartoli" title="Marion Bartoli">Marion Bartoli</a>, who was 4–0 up before a rain delay, which delayed the match a whole day. Sharapova then came back from a set down to win.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> In the semifinals Sharapova lost to world no. 1 Victoria Azarenka.
</p><p>Sharapova's next tournament was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Toray_Pan_Pacific_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Toray Pan Pacific Open – Singles (page does not exist)">Toray Pan Pacific Open</a> in Tokyo. She made it to the quarterfinals, losing to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Samantha_Stosur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Samantha Stosur (page does not exist)">Samantha Stosur</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_China_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 China Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">China Open</a> she was seeded second. In the finals she was again defeated by Azarenka.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> Sharapova's next tournament was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_WTA_Tour_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 WTA Tour Championships (page does not exist)">year-end championships</a> in Istanbul, where she was seeded <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_WTA_Tour_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 WTA Tour Championships – Singles (page does not exist)">second</a>. She defeated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sara_Errani&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sara Errani (page does not exist)">Sara Errani</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agnieszka_Radwa%C5%84ska&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agnieszka Radwańska (page does not exist)">Agnieszka Radwańska</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Samantha_Stosur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Samantha Stosur (page does not exist)">Samantha Stosur</a> in the round-robin matches. In the semifinals, Sharapova beat Azarenka, bringing their head-to-head meetings to 7–5 in Azarenka's favour. Although Sharapova made it to the final, Azarenka clinched the year-end no. 1 ranking with her two round-robin wins. She lost to Serena Williams for the 13th consecutive time in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2013:_Continued_success.2C_return_of_shoulder_injury">2013: Continued success, return of shoulder injury</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_-_Roland-Garros_2013_-_002.jpg" title="File:Maria Sharapova - Roland-Garros 2013 - 002.jpg">File:Maria Sharapova - Roland-Garros 2013 - 002.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova at <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Roland_Garros&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Roland Garros (page does not exist)">2011 Roland Garros</a></div></div></div>
<p>Sharapova's first scheduled tournament of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_WTA_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 WTA Tour (page does not exist)">2013 season</a> was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_Brisbane_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 Brisbane International (page does not exist)">Brisbane International</a>, where she was seeded second. However, she withdrew from the tournament before it began, citing a collarbone injury.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> She started her season at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 Australian Open (page does not exist)">Australian Open</a> seeded second. She defeated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Olga_Puchkova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Olga Puchkova (page does not exist)">Olga Puchkova</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Misaki_Doi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Misaki Doi (page does not exist)">Misaki Doi</a> in the first two rounds without losing a game in either match, the first time a player has won in back-to-back <a href="/w/index.php?title=Double_bagel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Double bagel (page does not exist)">double bagels</a> at a Grand Slam tournament since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1985_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1985 Australian Open (page does not exist)">1985 Australian Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> Sharapova then defeated <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus Williams</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kirsten_Flipkens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kirsten Flipkens (page does not exist)">Kirsten Flipkens</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ekaterina_Makarova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ekaterina Makarova (page does not exist)">Ekaterina Makarova</a>, where in losing only nine games she broke <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a>' record of fewest games dropped heading into a Grand Slam semifinal.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> She lost to <a href="/wiki/Li_Na_(tennis)" title="Li Na (tennis)">Li Na</a> in the semifinals. Maria was ruthlessly crushed by Li Na 6-2 6-2.
</p><p>She reached the semifinals at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qatar_Total_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qatar Total Open (page does not exist)">Qatar Total Open</a>, losing to <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> for the 10th straight time in her career.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> Her next tournament was <a href="/w/index.php?title=BNP_Paribas_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BNP Paribas Open (page does not exist)">Indian Wells</a>, where she was seeded second. She received a bye into the second round and successfully reached the final without dropping a set, where she faced 2011 Indian wells champion and former world no. 1 <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Wozniacki" title="Caroline Wozniacki">Caroline Wozniacki</a>. After an hour and twenty-one minutes, Sharapova won the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> This was Maria's 28th career title and second at Indian Wells. Her win also made her the no. 2 player in the world behind <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>Maria then competed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_Sony_Open_Tennis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 Sony Open Tennis (page does not exist)">Sony Open</a>. Once again she reached the final without dropping a set and faced world no. 1 <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a>. Maria started the match strong, winning the first set. However, Serena won the second and dominated the third set. This was Maria's 11th consecutive loss against Serena.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>Next, she played at the indoor clay event in Stuttgart, where she was the defending champion. Maria was top seed and had a bye in the first round. Her first three matches were long three-setters: she first beat world no. 25 <a href="/wiki/Lucie_%C5%A0af%C3%A1%C5%99ov%C3%A1" title="Lucie Šafářová">Lucie Šafářová</a>, dropping the second set on a tiebreak, then <a href="/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic" title="Ana Ivanovic">Ana Ivanovic</a>, then in the semifinals she won against third seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Angelique_Kerber&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Angelique Kerber (page does not exist)">Angelique Kerber</a>. In the final, in what was her ninth victory against the Chinese out of 14 matches, she beat second seed world no. 5 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Na_Li_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Na Li (tennis) (page does not exist)">Li Na</a> in straight sets to win her 29th career title.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>A week later, she competed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_Mutua_Madrid_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 Mutua Madrid Open (page does not exist)">Madrid Open</a>, reaching the final, again without dropping a set. She faced <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> for the 15th time, losing for the 12th consecutive time in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>Next, she played in Rome, where she was seeded second and had a bye in the first round. She beat 16th seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sloane_Stephens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sloane Stephens (page does not exist)">Sloane Stephens</a> in straight sets (with the loss of just three games) in the third round, but then did not play her quarterfinal match against seventh seed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sara_Errani&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sara Errani (page does not exist)">Sara Errani</a> and retired from the tournament due to a viral illness.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_French_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 French Open (page does not exist)">2013 French Open</a>, Sharapova reached the final again, beating Azarenka in three sets in the semifinals, but there she lost in straight sets to <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a>. At <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_Wimbledon_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 Wimbledon Championships (page does not exist)">Wimbledon</a> she was comprehensively beaten in the second round by qualifier <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michelle_Larcher_de_Brito&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michelle Larcher de Brito (page does not exist)">Michelle Larcher de Brito</a>. Sharapova then returned to the tour at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_Western_%26_Southern_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 Western &amp; Southern Open (page does not exist)">2013 Western &amp; Southern Open</a>, where she lost her opening match to an in-form Sloane Stephens 6-2 (5)6-7 3-6. A week later Sharapova withdrew from the U.S. Open citing an alleged "shoulder injury", which prematurely ended her season.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2014:_Comeback_from_shoulder_injury">2014: Comeback from shoulder injury</span></h3>
<p>Sharapova had not played since August 2013 due to a recurring shoulder injury and made her comeback at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2014_Brisbane_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2014 Brisbane International (page does not exist)">2014 Brisbane International</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>  Sharapova advanced to the semi-finals where she was beaten in straight sets by <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> 6-2, 7-6 (9-7).
</p><p>At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2014_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2014 Australian Open (page does not exist)">2014 Australian Open</a> Sharapova, ranked 3rd, was bundled out of the tournament in the 4th round by the 20th seed Slovakian, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominika_Cibulkova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominika Cibulkova (page does not exist)">Dominika Cibulkova</a>.  Sharapova lost the game in 3 sets, 6-3, 4-6, 1-6.  The loss was just the second time she has been knocked out before the quarter-finals.  The last time was in 2004.Sharapova then participated in GDF Suez open where she lost to the younger Russian Pavlyuchenkova in 3sets.Sharapova is currently ranked 5th.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Fed_Cup_participation">Fed Cup participation</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sharapova_hitting_backhand.JPG" title="File:Sharapova hitting backhand.JPG">File:Sharapova hitting backhand.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova playing for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russia_Fed_Cup_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russia Fed Cup team (page does not exist)">Russian</a> <a href="/wiki/Fed_Cup" title="Fed Cup">Fed Cup</a> team against <a href="/w/index.php?title=Israel_Fed_Cup_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Israel Fed Cup team (page does not exist)">Israel</a> in 2008.</div></div></div>
<p>Sharapova has lived in the United States since moving there at the age of seven, but retains her Russian citizenship, and is therefore eligible to play in the <a href="/wiki/Fed_Cup" title="Fed Cup">Fed Cup</a> for Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-pravda_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pravda-146">[146]</a></sup> However, the behavior of Sharapova's father during her matches on the WTA Tour, combined with a perceived lack of commitment by her to the Fed Cup, has made her selection for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russia_Fed_Cup_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russia Fed Cup team (page does not exist)">Russian Fed Cup team</a> cause controversy in the past.
</p><p>After Sharapova had beaten fellow Russian <a href="/wiki/Anastasia_Myskina" title="Anastasia Myskina">Anastasia Myskina</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2004_WTA_Tour_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2004 WTA Tour Championships (page does not exist)">2004 WTA Tour Championships</a>, Myskina criticized Sharapova's father, saying: "He was just yelling and screaming instructions to her and I thought he just might jump right on the court at one point in the match." At the Fed Cup semifinals two weeks later, Myskina stated she would stop playing for Russia if Sharapova joined the Russian team the following season: "If she joins our team next season you won't see me there for sure. His behaviour is totally incorrect, simply rude. I don't want to be around people like him." <a href="/w/index.php?title=Larisa_Neiland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Larisa Neiland (page does not exist)">Larisa Neiland</a>, assistant to Russia Fed Cup captain Shamil Tarpishchev, added: "Her father's behaviour (at the WTA Tour Championships) was simply outrageous. I just don't see how he could work with the rest of us." However Tarpishchev himself played down the problem, insisting: "I feel that things will calm down soon and we'll have Myskina, Sharapova, Kuznetsova and everyone else playing for Russia."<sup id="cite_ref-myskina_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-myskina-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_in_Russian_team_uniform.JPG" title="File:Maria Sharapova in Russian team uniform.JPG">File:Maria Sharapova in Russian team uniform.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova playing for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russia_Fed_Cup_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russia Fed Cup team (page does not exist)">Russian Fed Cup team</a></div></div></div>
<p>At the end of 2005, Sharapova stated she was now keen to make her Fed Cup debut<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> and was set to play against Belgium in April 2006, but withdrew.<sup id="cite_ref-sharapovadelays_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sharapovadelays-149">[149]</a></sup>
She later withdrew from ties against Spain in April 2007<sup id="cite_ref-missfedcup_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-missfedcup-150">[150]</a></sup> and against the United States in July 2007 because of injuries.<sup id="cite_ref-pulloutangers_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pulloutangers-151">[151]</a></sup> The latter withdrawal led to Russia's captain saying she would be "ineligible for selection" for the Fed Cup final in September.<sup id="cite_ref-forfedcup_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forfedcup-152">[152]</a></sup> However, Sharapova attended the final, cheering from the sidelines and acting as a "hitting partner" in practices, resulting in some of her Russian teammates implying that she was attending only to enable her to play at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tennis_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics (page does not exist)">2008 Beijing Olympics</a> (rules state that players must have "shown commitment" to Fed Cup in order to play). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Svetlana_Kuznetsova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Svetlana Kuznetsova (page does not exist)">Svetlana Kuznetsova</a> said, "She said she wanted to be our practice partner but if you can't play how then can you practice?"<sup id="cite_ref-rowover_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rowover-153">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova finally made her Fed Cup debut in February 2008, in Russia's quarterfinal tie against <a href="/w/index.php?title=Israel_Fed_Cup_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Israel Fed Cup team (page does not exist)">Israel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Fedcupdebut_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fedcupdebut-154">[154]</a></sup> She won both her singles rubbers, against <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tzipora_Obziler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tzipora Obziler (page does not exist)">Tzipora Obziler</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shahar_Pe%27er&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shahar Pe'er (page does not exist)">Shahar Pe'er</a>, helping Russia to a 4–1 victory.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> For the semifinals, she was given permission to skip the tie, with Tarpishchev announcing that she will be on the team for the final.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> However, the date of the final coincided with the lay-off from her shoulder injury, and thus she did not play.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 2011 first-round tie, Sharapova played <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginie_Razzano&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginie Razzano (page does not exist)">Virginie Razzano</a> of France and lost. Sharapova was supposed to play <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aliz%C3%A9_Cornet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alizé Cornet (page does not exist)">Alizé Cornet</a> but she was suffering from a viral illness.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> Teammate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anastasia_Pavlyuchenkova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova (page does not exist)">Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova</a> played and defeated Cornet to secure the 3–2 win for Russia against France. Sharapova continued to participate in 2012 and helped Russia to a 3–2 win against Spain in the first-round tie. Sharapova defeated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Silvia_Soler_Espinosa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Silvia Soler Espinosa (page does not exist)">Silvia Soler Espinosa</a> in the first rubber, but was unable to play her second rubber due to illness.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Playing_style">Playing style</span></h2>
<p>Sharapova is an aggressive baseliner with power, depth, and angles on her forehand and backhand.<sup id="cite_ref-profile_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-profile-160">[160]</a></sup> She is one of the few players on the WTA tour who often uses the reverse forehand. Instead of using a traditional <a href="/wiki/Volley_(tennis)" title="Volley (tennis)">volley</a> or overhead <a href="/wiki/Smash_(tennis)" title="Smash (tennis)">smash</a>, she prefers to hit a powerful "swinging" volley when approaching the net or attacking <a href="/wiki/Lob_(tennis)" title="Lob (tennis)">lobs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> Sharapova is thought to have good speed around the court, especially considering her height.<sup id="cite_ref-profile_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-profile-160">[160]</a></sup> At the beginning of 2008, some observers noted that Sharapova had developed her game, showing improved movement and footwork and the addition of a <a href="/wiki/Drop_shot" title="Drop shot">drop shot</a> and sliced backhand to her repertoire of shots.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> Despite her powerful game, Sharapova's greatest asset is considered to be her mental toughness and competitive spirit, with Nick Bollettieri stating that she is "tough as nails". Hall-of-famer <a href="/wiki/John_McEnroe" title="John McEnroe">John McEnroe</a> said of Sharapova, "she's one of the best competitors in the history of the sport."<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> Sharapova is known for on-court "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Grunting_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grunting (tennis) (page does not exist)">grunting</a>", which reached a recorded 101 <a href="/wiki/Decibel" title="Decibel">decibels</a> during a match at <a href="/wiki/2005_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2005 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon in 2005</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-grunting_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grunting-165">[165]</a></sup> During her second round match in Birmingham in 2003, Sharapova was asked to tone down the level of her grunt after opponent <a href="/wiki/Nathalie_Dechy" title="Nathalie Dechy">Nathalie Dechy</a> complained to the umpire, with Sharapova's response saying that her grunting was "a natural instinct."<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a> suggested that grunting is involuntary and a part of tennis.<sup id="cite_ref-GruntTelegraph_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GruntTelegraph-167">[167]</a></sup> When questioned by the media about her grunting, Sharapova urged the media to "just watch the match."<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> Her defensive game has been worked on by her new coach, and this has reflected in her results, making consecutive semi-finals at premier mandatory events on the tour.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Serve">Serve</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_at_the_2009_Wimbledon_Championships_12.jpg" title="File:Maria Sharapova at the 2009 Wimbledon Championships 12.jpg">File:Maria Sharapova at the 2009 Wimbledon Championships 12.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova at The Championships, Wimbledon in 2009.</div></div></div>
<p>Early in her career Sharapova's first and second serves were regarded as powerful,<sup id="cite_ref-profile_160-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-profile-160">[160]</a></sup> and she was believed to possess one of the best deliveries on the Tour.<sup id="cite_ref-Serve1_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serve1-169">[169]</a></sup> Since the beginning of 2007, however, problems with her shoulder have reduced the effectiveness of her serve.<sup id="cite_ref-Serve1_169-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serve1-169">[169]</a></sup> The shoulder injury not only resulted in her inconsistent first serves, but also her hitting high numbers of double faults.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> Two-time US Open singles champion <a href="/wiki/Tracy_Austin" title="Tracy Austin">Tracy Austin</a> believes that Sharapova often loses confidence in the rest of her game when she experiences problems with her serve and consequently produces more unforced errors and generally plays more tentatively,<sup id="cite_ref-austin_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-austin-171">[171]</a></sup> while tennis writer Joel Drucker remarked that her serve was the "catalyst for her entire game", and that her struggles with it left her "unmasked."<sup id="cite_ref-Serve1_169-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serve1-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>In her return from layoff in 2008 to 2009, she used an abbreviated motion, which was somewhat less powerful, and though producing aces also gave a very high number of double faults. After her early loss at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">2009 US Open</a>, Sharapova returned to a more elongated motion, similar to her pre-surgery serve. She has since been able to produce speeds greater than before, including a 121&#160;mph serve hit at the Birmingham tournament in 2010 – the fastest serve of her career.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>However since her shoulder operation Sharapova has been unable to control her serve. This has led to numerous faults, as she is unable to feel how much power she is generating.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> The new action led to an elbow injury, but under Thomas Högstedt it has improved but can still be erratic.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> This improvement in serving can be seen in the 2013 Australian Open and following tournaments where Maria Sharapova committed fewer double faults than in previous years.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Surfaces">Surfaces</span></h3>
<p>Because she predicates her game on power, Sharapova's preferred surfaces are the fast-playing hard and grass courts, as evident through her 25 victories on hard court and grass court. This is most notable when she won the <a href="/wiki/2004_Wimbledon" title="2004 Wimbledon" class="mw-redirect">2004 Wimbledon</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">2006 U.S. Open</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Australian Open (page does not exist)">2008 Australian Open</a> crowns, where she had her career breakthrough and played her peak tennis level, respectively.
</p><p>Sharapova, however, is not as well-suited to the slower clay courts as she is on hard and grass courts. Sharapova has admitted that she is not as comfortable with her movement on clay compared with other court surfaces and once described herself as like a "cow on ice" after a match on clay,<sup id="cite_ref-cow_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cow-175">[175]</a></sup> due to her inability to slide. Despite this, she has shown improvement on this surface with respect to experience, as evident with her first WTA red clay title at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_Internationaux_de_Strasbourg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 Internationaux de Strasbourg (page does not exist)">2010 Internationaux de Strasbourg</a>, 7 years since playing on the WTA circuit. Less than a year later, she won her biggest red clay title at the Tier I <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Internazionali BNL d'Italia (page does not exist)">2011 Internazionali BNL d'Italia</a>. Sharapova is still showing rapid improvement on clay courts as evident by winning the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Porsche_Tennis_Grand_Prix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Porsche Tennis Grand Prix (page does not exist)">2012 Porsche Tennis Grand Prix</a> in Stuttgart and then a month later successfully defending her 2011 title in Rome, by winning the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Internazionali BNL d'Italia (page does not exist)">2012 Internazionali BNL d'Italia</a>, and then winning the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_French_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 French Open (page does not exist)">2012 French Open</a>, her best clay court season to date with a win/loss record of 19–1, with a total loss of four sets the entire clay court season.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_in_Belarus_UNDP-1.jpg" title="File:Maria Sharapova in Belarus UNDP-1.jpg">File:Maria Sharapova in Belarus UNDP-1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova with children in <a href="/wiki/Gomel" title="Gomel">Gomel</a>, an area affected by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chernobyl_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chernobyl nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Chernobyl nuclear disaster</a> in 1986.</div></div></div>
<p>Sharapova has lived in the United States since moving there at the age of seven. Besides a home in <a href="/wiki/Bradenton" title="Bradenton" class="mw-redirect">Bradenton</a>, Florida, she also has a residence in <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Beach,_California" title="Manhattan Beach, California">Manhattan Beach, California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-peoplemagazine_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peoplemagazine-176">[176]</a></sup> Sharapova was engaged to Slovenian professional basketball player <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sasha_Vuja%C4%8Di%C4%87&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sasha Vujačić (page does not exist)">Sasha Vujačić</a>, who plays for the <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_Efes_S.K." title="Anadolu Efes S.K.">Anadolu Efes S.K.</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Istanbul,_Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Istanbul, Turkey (page does not exist)">Istanbul, Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> The two had been dating since 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> On August 31, 2012, Sharapova confirmed that the engagement was off and that they had broken up in spring of 2012. From 2005–2011, Sharapova has been named in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Forbes_Celebrity_100&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forbes Celebrity 100 (page does not exist)">Forbes Celebrity 100</a>. This lists her as one of the top 100 most powerful celebrities of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova has made varying remarks on how long she intends to maintain her tennis career. Following the retirement of 25-year-old <a href="/wiki/Justine_Henin" title="Justine Henin">Justine Henin</a> in 2008, Sharapova said, "If I was 25 and I'd won so many Grand Slams, I'd quit too."<sup id="cite_ref-henin_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-henin-181">[181]</a></sup> In an interview after the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Australian Open (page does not exist)">2008 Australian Open</a>, she balked at the idea of playing for another ten years, saying that she hoped to have a "nice husband and a few kids" by then.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> However in an interview before her <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Australian_Open&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Australian Open (page does not exist)">2012 Australian Open</a> semifinal, Sharapova changed her stance, saying she intended to continue playing tennis for as long as she enjoyed playing the game. Sharapova stated "I'm sure when I was 17 years old and someone said, you'll be playing for another eight years, it would be like, you're not going to see me at a press conference at 25 years old. But years go on. I missed a year in my career—I didn't play that year. I've said this, just before the tournament, a few weeks before, I woke up and I was just so happy to be going back on the court. I felt so fresh, full of energy, just with a really good perspective. Times change, obviously. I see myself playing this sport for many more years because it's something that gives me the most pleasure in my life. I think it helps when you know you're good at something, and you can always improve it. It obviously helps with the encouragement."<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">2004 US Open</a>, Sharapova, along with several other Russian female tennis players, wore a black ribbon in observance of the tragedy after the <a href="/wiki/Beslan_school_hostage_crisis" title="Beslan school hostage crisis">Beslan school hostage crisis</a>, which took place only days before.<sup id="cite_ref-espn_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-espn-184">[184]</a></sup> In 2005, she donated around US$50,000 to those affected by the crisis.<sup id="cite_ref-wtacareer_33-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtacareer-33">[33]</a></sup> On February 14, 2007, Sharapova was appointed a <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNDP_Goodwill_Ambassador&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNDP Goodwill Ambassador (page does not exist)">Goodwill Ambassador</a> for the <a href="/wiki/UNDP" title="UNDP" class="mw-redirect">United Nations Development Programme</a> (UNDP) and donated US$210,000 to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chernobyl_Recovery_and_Development_Programme_(CRDP)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chernobyl Recovery and Development Programme (CRDP) (page does not exist)">UNDP Chernobyl-recovery projects</a>. She stated at the time that she was planning to travel back to the area after Wimbledon in 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-usatoday_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usatoday-185">[185]</a></sup> though it didn't happen, as she had to travel back to the US because of shoulder injury.<sup id="cite_ref-wimbledon_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wimbledon-186">[186]</a></sup> She fulfilled the trip in late June – early July 2010. Sharapova has helped to promote the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> In addition, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Angela_Haynes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Angela Haynes (page does not exist)">Angela Haynes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maria_Kirilenko" title="Maria Kirilenko">Maria Kirilenko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nicole_Vaidi%C5%A1ov%C3%A1" title="Nicole Vaidišová">Nicole Vaidišová</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rennae_Stubbs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rennae Stubbs (page does not exist)">Rennae Stubbs</a>, Governor <a href="/wiki/Jeb_Bush" title="Jeb Bush">Jeb Bush</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Capriati" title="Jennifer Capriati">Jennifer Capriati</a>, Sharapova participated in an exhibition in Tampa in December 2004, raising money for the Florida Hurricane Relief Fund.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> In July 2008, Sharapova sent a message on DVD to the memorial service of cancer victim Emily Bailes, who had performed the coin toss ahead of the <a href="/wiki/2004_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2004 Wimbledon Championships">2004 Wimbledon final</a> that Sharapova had gone on to win.<sup id="cite_ref-bbcnews_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcnews-189">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Endorsements">Endorsements</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_and_her_Canon_Powershot_Diamond_Collection.jpg" title="File:Maria Sharapova and her Canon Powershot Diamond Collection.jpg">File:Maria Sharapova and her Canon Powershot Diamond Collection.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sharapova unveiling the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canon_PowerShot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canon PowerShot (page does not exist)">Canon PowerShot</a> Diamond lineup of digital cameras.</div></div></div>
<p>Sharapova's tennis success and appearance have enabled her to secure commercial endorsements that greatly exceed the value of her tournament winnings.<sup id="cite_ref-marcganis_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marcganis-190">[190]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hbswk_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hbswk-191">[191]</a></sup> In March 2006, Forbes magazine listed her as the highest-paid female athlete in the world, with annual earnings of over US $18&#160;million,<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> the majority of which was from endorsements and sponsorships. She has topped that list every year since, even after her 2007 shoulder injury.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> In 2011, <i>Forbes</i> listed Sharapova as No.&#160;29 in their list of 50 top-paid athletes, the only woman on the list.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> In 2012, she was listed as No.&#160;15, and was joined in the top 20 by <a href="/wiki/Li_Na_(tennis)" title="Li Na (tennis)">Li Na</a> at No.&#160;16 and <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> at No.&#160;17.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> In April 2005, <i><a href="/wiki/People_(magazine)" title="People (magazine)">People</a></i> named her one of the 50 most beautiful celebrities in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup>  In 2006, <i><a href="/wiki/Maxim_(magazine)" title="Maxim (magazine)">Maxim</a></i> ranked Sharapova the hottest athlete in the world for the fourth consecutive year. She posed in a six-page bikini photoshoot spread in the 2006 <a href="/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day" title="Valentine's Day">Valentine's Day</a> issue of the <i><a href="/wiki/Sports_Illustrated_Swimsuit_Issue" title="Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue">Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue</a></i>, alongside 25 supermodels.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> In a poll run by Britain's <i><a href="/wiki/FHM" title="FHM">FHM</a></i> magazine, she was voted the seventh most eligible bachelorette,<sup id="cite_ref-newscomau_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newscomau-200">[200]</a></sup> based on both "wealth and looks."
</p><p>Immediately after her win at the 2004 Wimbledon Championship, mobile phone company <a href="/wiki/Motorola" title="Motorola">Motorola</a> signed Sharapova to endorse their mobile phone line.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup> Additionally, she appeared in commercials for <a href="/wiki/Land_Rover" title="Land Rover">Land Rover</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canon_(company)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canon (company) (page does not exist)">Canon</a>, as well as approved of namesake items by watch brand <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tag_Heuer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tag Heuer (page does not exist)">Tag Heuer</a> and jeweller <a href="/wiki/Tiffany_%26_Co." title="Tiffany &amp; Co.">Tiffany</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup> Tiffany also provides Sharapova with earrings from the "Tiffany for Maria Sharapova" collection at the four major events, that are also retailed globally.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> She also starred in an award winning campaign for the sports clothing brand Nike, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pretty_(advertisement)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pretty (advertisement) (page does not exist)">Pretty</a>", in the summer of 2006. She signed a sponsorship deal in January 2007 with Gatorade and Tropicana.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> In 2007, Sharapova was featured in a number of Canon USA's commercials for the PowerShot.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> Sharapova has also been depicted in many tennis-related video games. Some of the titles include the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Top_Spin_(video_game)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Top Spin (video game) (page does not exist)">Top Spin series</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Virtua_Tennis" title="Virtua Tennis">Virtua Tennis</a></i> series, and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_Tennis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grand Slam Tennis (page does not exist)">Grand Slam Tennis</a></i> series. During the layoff due to her shoulder surgery, sensing the fleeting nature of a professional athlete's career, Sharapova decided to focus on developing her name as a brand, beginning with meeting with her sponsors more extensively to further her brand.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup> In January 2010, it was announced that Sharapova had renewed her contract with Nike, signing an 8 year deal for $70&#160;million. This is the most lucrative deal ever for a sportswoman, dwarfing the previous record, which was Venus Williams' $43&#160;million deal with Reebok.<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian-205">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following in the footsteps of tennis players who started clothing lines such as <a href="/wiki/Fred_Perry" title="Fred Perry">Fred Perry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Lacoste" title="René Lacoste">René Lacoste</a>, Sharapova launched her own tennis apparel line, the "Nike Maria Sharapova Collection", in 2010. The collection includes dresses that she designed for all the major tournaments, in collaboration with Nike and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cole_Haan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cole Haan (page does not exist)">Cole Haan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn-ms_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-ms-206">[206]</a></sup> She had previously found that the outfits given to her by Nike did not suit her frame and were worn by too many other players.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup> She comes up with design ideas and sketches in a process that begins 18 months before the event<sup id="cite_ref-cnn-ms_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-ms-206">[206]</a></sup> and receives royalties from the sale of the collection, of which the corresponding dresses are coordinated to be available simultaneously with the corresponding major tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup> The collection is worn by other WTA players, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sofia_Arvidsson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sofia Arvidsson (page does not exist)">Sofia Arvidsson</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eugenie_Bouchard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eugenie Bouchard (page does not exist)">Eugenie Bouchard</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kai-Chen_Chang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kai-Chen Chang (page does not exist)">Kai-Chen Chang</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Andrea_Hlav%C3%A1%C4%8Dkov%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Andrea Hlaváčková (page does not exist)">Andrea Hlaváčková</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Madison_Keys&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Madison Keys (page does not exist)">Madison Keys</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anastasia_Pivovarova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anastasia Pivovarova (page does not exist)">Anastasia Pivovarova</a> as well as junior players such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indy_De_Vroome&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indy De Vroome (page does not exist)">Indy De Vroome</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn-ms_206-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-ms-206">[206]</a></sup> Sharapova had earlier collaborated with Nike on the "little black dress" that she wore for her night matches at the 2006 US Open.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup> The dress featured a round crystal studded collar and was inspired by <a href="/wiki/Audrey_Hepburn" title="Audrey Hepburn">Audrey Hepburn</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup> The dress was well publicized and received but was not mass-produced.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cnn-ms_206-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-ms-206">[206]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> Additionally, she designs shoes and handbags for Cole Haan, for which her signature ballerina flats are one of the biggest sellers of the entire brand.<sup id="cite_ref-nytdress_201-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytdress-201">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova used the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prince_Sports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prince Sports (page does not exist)">Prince</a> Triple Threat Hornet for part of 2003 and then used several different Prince racquets until the <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>. She gave the racquet she used in the <a href="/wiki/2004_Wimbledon" title="2004 Wimbledon" class="mw-redirect">2004 Wimbledon</a> final to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regis_Philbin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regis Philbin (page does not exist)">Regis Philbin</a> when taping <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Live_with_Regis_and_Kelly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Live with Regis and Kelly (page does not exist)">Live with Regis and Kelly</a></i>. Sharapova began using the Prince Shark OS at that tournament specially designed for her.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> She then switched to the Prince O3 White racquet in January 2006. She switched to the Prince O3 Speedport Black in July 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> After being with Prince for ten years,<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> Sharapova began endorsing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Head_(company)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Head (company) (page does not exist)">Head</a> racquets in 2011 and uses the Head YOUTEK IG Instinct.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sharapova signed a three-year deal to be brand ambassador for <a href="/wiki/Porsche" title="Porsche">Porsche</a> in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sugarpova">Sugarpova</span></h2>
<p>"Sugarpova" is a <a href="/wiki/Candy" title="Candy">candy</a> line created by Maria Sharapova and candy veteran Jeff Rubin, founder of international retailer <a href="/w/index.php?title=IT%27SUGAR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IT'SUGAR (page does not exist)">IT'SUGAR</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sugarpova_Candy:_Sharapova.27s_Sweet_Taste_of_Success_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sugarpova_Candy:_Sharapova.27s_Sweet_Taste_of_Success-214">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sharapova.27s_Sugarpova_lolly_range_.27smacks_of_irresponsible_marketing.27_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharapova.27s_Sugarpova_lolly_range_.27smacks_of_irresponsible_marketing.27-215">[215]</a></sup> According to the Sugarpova website, "Sugarpova is a premium candy line that reflects the fun, fashionable, sweet side of international tennis sensation Maria Sharapova."<sup id="cite_ref-sugarpova.com_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sugarpova.com-216">[216]</a></sup> The line currently consists of 12 different flavors that range from Flirty, to Smitten Sour, to Splashy.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> A portion of all proceeds go towards the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mariasharapova.com/foundation.aspx">Maria Sharapova Foundation</a>, Sharapova's charity.<sup id="cite_ref-sugarpova.com_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sugarpova.com-216">[216]</a></sup> Sugarpova was launched worldwide in 2013 through IT'SUGAR and <a href="/wiki/Selfridges" title="Selfridges">Selfridges</a> stores.  According to her agent, Sharapova seriously considered changing her last name to Sugarpova for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_US_Open_(tennis)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 US Open (tennis) (page does not exist)">2013 US Open</a>, but ultimately decided against it.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> However, some reports suggest that she made an application to the Supreme Court of Florida to that effect.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career_statistics">Career statistics</span></h2>

<p><small> <i>Note: At the <a href="/wiki/2003_Australian_Open" title="2003 Australian Open">2003 Australian Open</a> and <a href="/wiki/2003_French_Open" title="2003 French Open">2003 French Open</a>, Sharapova won three qualifying round matches at each tournament in order to enter the main draw.</i> </small>
</p>

</td></tr>

<td bgcolor="98FB98">Winner</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Australian Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2008</a></td>
<td>Australian Open</td>
<td>Hard</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_SRB&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data SRB (page does not exist)">Template:Country data SRB</a> <a href="/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic" title="Ana Ivanovic">Ana Ivanovic</a></td>
<td>7–5, 6–3
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cfc;">
<td bgcolor="FFA07A">Runner-up</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2011</a></td>
<td>Wimbledon</td>
<td>Grass</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_CZE&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data CZE (page does not exist)">Template:Country data CZE</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Petra_Kvitov%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Petra Kvitová (page does not exist)">Petra Kvitová</a></td>
<td>3–6, 4–6
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#ffc;">
<td bgcolor="FFA07A">Runner-up</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Australian Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2012</a></td>
<td>Australian Open <small>(2)</small></td>
<td>Hard</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_BLR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data BLR (page does not exist)">Template:Country data BLR</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victoria_Azarenka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victoria Azarenka (page does not exist)">Victoria Azarenka</a></td>
<td>3–6, 0–6
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#ebc2af;">
<td bgcolor="98FB98">Winner</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 French Open – Women's Singles (page does not exist)">2012</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a></td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Clay_court&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clay court (page does not exist)">Clay</a></td>

<td>6–3, 6–2
</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor="EBC2AF">
<td bgcolor="FFA07A">Runner-up</td>

<td>Clay</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_USA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data USA (page does not exist)">Template:Country data USA</a> Serena Williams</td>
<td>4–6, 4–6

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col (page does not exist)">Template:Div col</a>
</p>
<dl>
<dt>2003
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Newcomer of the Year<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Awards_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Awards-220">[220]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>2004
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>WTA Player of the Year<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>WTA Most Improved Player of the Year<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>2005
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=ESPY_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ESPY Awards (page does not exist)">ESPY</a> Best Female Tennis Player<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Prix de Citron Roland Garros<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>2006
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>Whirlpool 6th Sense Player of the Year<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>2007
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>ESPY Best Female Tennis Player<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>ESPY Best International Female Athlete<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>2008
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>ESPY Best Female Tennis Player<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>2010
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>WTA Fan Favorite Singles Player<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>WTA Humanitarian of the Year<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>WTA Most Fashionable Player (On Court)<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>WTA Most Fashionable Player (Off Court)<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>WTA Most Dramatic Expression<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_Info_221-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_Info-221">[221]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>2012
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>ESPY Best Female Tennis Player<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Order_of_Merit_for_the_Fatherland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Order of Merit for the Fatherland (page does not exist)">Medal of the Order For Merit to the Fatherland</a> 2nd Class (April 28, 2012) – <i>for her philanthropic activity</i><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Order_of_Merit_for_the_Fatherland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Order of Merit for the Fatherland (page does not exist)">Medal of the Order For Merit to the Fatherland</a> 1st Class (August 13, 2012) – <i>for her outstanding contribution to the development of physical cultures and sports at the XXX Olympic Games in 2012 in London (Great Britain)</i><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
